symptoms: Diamond-shaped lesions with grey center and dark border on leaves
Lesions on nodes causing neck blast
White to grey fungal growth on lesion surface
Severely infected leaves dry out
cause: Fungal pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae, spread by wind-borne spores. Favored by high humidity (>90%), moderate temperatures (25-28°C), and excessive nitrogen fertilization.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected plant debris
Apply Trichoderma viride @ 4g/kg seed as seed treatment
Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 5g/L water
Use neem oil spray (5ml/L) at early infection stage
prevention: Treat seeds with fungicide before sowing

symptoms: Oval to circular brown spots on leaves
Spots have grey or white center with brown margin
Spots may merge to form large patches
Dark brown spots on glumes causing grain discoloration
cause: Fungal pathogen Bipolaris oryzae (Helminthosporium oryzae). Favored by nutrient-deficient soils, especially low potassium and zinc.
organic_treatment: Improve soil nutrition with organic compost
Apply Trichoderma harzianum @ 4g/kg seed
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) at early stage
Apply zinc sulfate @ 25kg/ha to correct deficiency
prevention: Apply zinc sulfate as basal dose
Avoid water stress during critical growth stages

symptoms: Water-soaked lesions at leaf tips and margins
Lesions turn yellow and then white as they dry
Bacterial ooze (milky droplets) on leaf surface in morning
Leaves dry up from tip downward
cause: Bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas oryzae. Spread through irrigation water, rain splash, and wind. Favored by warm, humid weather and high nitrogen.
organic_treatment: Drain excess water from fields
Remove and burn infected plant residues
Apply neem cake @ 150kg/ha in soil
Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 5g/L water
prevention: Clip leaf tips during transplanting to reduce inoculum spread

symptoms: Yellow-orange pustules arranged in stripes along leaf veins
Pustules mainly on upper leaf surface
Severely infected leaves turn yellow and dry
Reduced grain filling
cause: Fungal pathogen Puccinia striiformis f. sp. tritici. Favored by cool temperatures (10-15°C) and high humidity. Wind-dispersed spores.
organic_treatment: Remove volunteer wheat plants that harbor spores
Apply Trichoderma viride as soil treatment
Use neem-based formulations for early infection
prevention: Monitor fields regularly from December to February
Apply first spray at initial rust appearance

symptoms: Orange-brown circular pustules scattered on upper leaf surface
Pustules do not follow vein pattern (unlike stripe rust)
Leaves turn brown and dry prematurely
Reduced grain weight
cause: Fungal pathogen Puccinia triticina. Favored by moderate temperatures (15-22°C) and humid conditions.
organic_treatment: Practice crop rotation
Destroy volunteer wheat and grassy weeds
Apply Trichoderma-based biocontrol agents

symptoms: Dark brown concentric rings (target-like spots) on lower/older leaves
Yellow halo around spots
Spots enlarge and cause leaf drop starting from bottom
Dark, sunken lesions on stems and fruit
cause: Fungal pathogen Alternaria solani. Survives in soil and plant debris. Favored by warm (24-29°C), humid conditions and poor nutrition.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy lower infected leaves immediately
Apply neem oil spray (5ml/L) every 7-10 days
Spray Trichoderma viride @ 4g/L water
Apply compost tea as foliar spray
prevention: Practice 2-3 year crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops
Stake tomato plants for air circulation
Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash

symptoms: Large dark, water-soaked patches on leaves
White fuzzy fungal growth on underside of leaves in humid conditions
Rapid browning and death of entire leaf
Dark greasy spots on fruits
Plants can be killed within 1-2 weeks
cause: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans. Thrives in cool (15-22°C), wet conditions with prolonged leaf wetness. Spreads very rapidly.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy ALL infected plant parts immediately
Spray copper-based Bordeaux mixture (1%)
Apply Trichoderma harzianum preventively
Improve air circulation by proper spacing
prevention: Use resistant varieties (Arka Rakshak, Arka Samrat)
Apply preventive fungicide sprays during rainy season
Destroy infected plant debris by burning

symptoms: Upward curling of leaves with thickening
Leaves become leathery and crinkled
Yellowing along leaf margins
Stunted plant growth with short internodes
Flower drop and reduced fruit set
cause: Viral infection transmitted by whitefly (Bemisia tabaci). Once infected, there is no cure — management focuses on vector control.
organic_treatment: Remove infected plants immediately and destroy
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) to repel whiteflies
Install yellow sticky traps around the field
Release natural predators (Encarsia formosa)
prevention: Use ToLCV-resistant varieties (Arka Rakshak, Arka Ananya)
Raise seedlings under insect-proof net house
Avoid planting near old infected tomato fields
Control whitefly population from seedling stage
Use reflective silver mulch to repel whiteflies

symptoms: Bore holes in squares, flowers, and bolls
Larval frass (excrement) visible near bore holes
Damaged bolls do not open properly
Shedding of squares and young bolls
cause: Lepidopteran pest Helicoverpa armigera. Polyphagous pest with multiple generations per season. Larvae bore into reproductive structures.
organic_treatment: Install pheromone traps (Helilure) @ 5/ha for monitoring
Release Trichogramma egg parasitoids @ 1.5 lakh/ha
Spray HaNPV (nuclear polyhedrosis virus) @ 250 LE/ha
Apply neem seed kernel extract (NSKE) 5%
prevention: Grow Bt cotton varieties where permitted
Practice trap cropping (marigold, castor) around cotton fields
Deep plough after harvest to destroy pupae

symptoms: Yellowing and wilting of leaves, usually on one side of plant
Brown discoloration of vascular tissue (visible on cutting stem)
Drooping of leaves even with adequate moisture
Stunted growth and premature death of plant
cause: Soil-borne fungal pathogen Fusarium oxysporum. Persists in soil for many years. Favored by light sandy soils and root-knot nematode infestation.
organic_treatment: Apply Trichoderma viride @ 4g/kg seed treatment
Add neem cake @ 250kg/ha to soil
Apply farm yard manure (FYM) @ 10 tons/ha
Soil solarization during summer months
prevention: Practice long crop rotation (4-5 years) with cereals

symptoms: Dark brown to black water-soaked lesions on leaves starting from tips/margins
White fungal growth on lower leaf surface
Rapid defoliation in severe cases
Brown, firm rot on tubers extending inward
cause: Oomycete Phytophthora infestans. Most destructive potato disease worldwide. Thrives in cool, wet weather (10-20°C).
organic_treatment: Apply Bordeaux mixture 1% as preventive spray
Remove and destroy all infected plant debris
Hill up soil around plants to protect tubers
Use Trichoderma viride as soil treatment
prevention: Plant resistant varieties (Kufri Jyoti, Kufri Girdhari)
Start preventive sprays from 30 days after planting

symptoms: Sunken circular spots on fruits with concentric rings
Spots turn dark brown to black
Salmon-colored spore masses in center of spots
Fruits shrivel and dry up (mummified)
cause: Fungal pathogen Colletotrichum capsici. Seed-borne and survives on crop debris. Spread by rain splash. Favored by warm humid weather.
organic_treatment: Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride @ 4g/kg
Remove and destroy infected fruits promptly
Spray Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 5g/L
Apply neem oil (5ml/L) as preventive

symptoms: Black irregular spots on leaves, flowers, and fruits
Blossom blight causing flower drop
Dark sunken lesions on ripe fruits
Twig dieback from tip downward
cause: Fungal pathogen Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Spread by rain and wind during flowering. Favored by warm (25-30°C) and humid conditions.
organic_treatment: Prune and destroy infected twigs and branches
Spray Bordeaux mixture 1% before flowering
Apply neem oil (5ml/L) at panicle emergence
Dip harvested fruits in hot water (52°C for 5 min)
prevention: Prune trees for good air circulation and sunlight penetration
Remove fallen leaves and fruit from orchard floor
Apply preventive spray at bud burst and flowering stages

symptoms: White powdery fungal coating on upper leaf surface
Powdery patches may spread to stems, flowers, and fruits
Affected leaves curl upward and may drop prematurely
Reduced photosynthesis leading to poor growth
cause: Obligate fungal parasites (Erysiphe, Oidium species). Unlike most fungi, thrives in DRY warm conditions (20-28°C) with moderate humidity.
organic_treatment: Spray milk solution (1 part milk : 9 parts water)
Apply sulfur-based organic fungicide (wettable sulfur 3g/L)
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) at early infection
Remove severely infected plant parts
prevention: Ensure adequate spacing for air movement
Monitor crops during dry, warm weather

symptoms: Yellow angular patches on upper leaf surface (between veins)
Grey-purple fuzzy growth on lower leaf surface
Leaves curl, brown, and die from edges
In grapes: brown patches on berries and shoot tips
cause: Oomycete pathogens (Peronospora, Pseudoperonospora, Sclerospora). Spread by wind and water splash. Thrives in cool (15-22°C), WET conditions with prolonged leaf wetness.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant parts
Apply Bordeaux mixture 1% as preventive spray
Improve air circulation by proper spacing and pruning
Avoid evening irrigation
prevention: Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest
Apply preventive sprays during wet weather

symptoms: Small circular spots with grey-white center and dark brown-purple border
Spots may have yellow halo
Multiple spots merge causing large dead areas
Severe defoliation in heavy infections
cause: Fungal pathogen Cercospora species. Survives on crop residues. Spread by wind-borne spores and rain splash. Favored by warm (25-35°C), humid weather.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves
Apply Trichoderma viride @ 4g/L as foliar spray
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) preventively
Practice mulching to reduce soil splash
prevention: Practice crop rotation with non-host crops

symptoms: Sudden permanent wilting of entire plant or branches
No yellowing before wilting (green wilt)
Brown discoloration of vascular tissue inside stem
Bacterial ooze test: cut stem placed in water shows milky bacterial stream
cause: Soil-borne bacterium Ralstonia solanacearum. Enters through roots and wounds. Favored by warm (28-35°C) and waterlogged soils. Very persistent in soil.
organic_treatment: Remove and burn all infected plants immediately
Apply Pseudomonas fluorescens @ 10g/L as soil drench
Add neem cake @ 250kg/ha to soil
Soil solarization in summer (cover with transparent plastic for 45 days)
chemical_treatment: Streptocycline @ 0.5g/L + Copper oxychloride 3g/L as soil drench
prevention: Practice long crop rotation (5-6 years) with paddy or cereals
Avoid waterlogging and ensure proper drainage
Avoid injury to roots during weeding
Solarize nursery beds before seedling production

symptoms: Irregular white or pale serpentine mines (tunnels) on leaf surface
Mines created by larvae feeding between leaf layers
Heavily mined leaves dry up and fall
Small black puncture marks on upper leaf surface (feeding/egg-laying sites)
cause: Dipteran flies (Liriomyza species). Female flies puncture leaves for feeding and laying eggs. Larvae mine through leaf tissue between upper and lower epidermis.
organic_treatment: Install yellow sticky traps to catch adult flies
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) to deter egg-laying
Remove and destroy heavily mined leaves
Encourage natural enemies (parasitic wasps)
prevention: Remove weeds that serve as alternate hosts

symptoms: Orange-brown to reddish-brown raised pustules on leaf surfaces
Pustules release powdery orange spores when rubbed
Severe infection causes leaf yellowing and premature drying
Reduced grain/fruit quality and yield
cause: Obligate fungal parasites (Puccinia, Uromyces species). Wind-dispersed spores can travel long distances. Favored by moderate temperatures and high humidity.
organic_treatment: Remove infected plant debris
Apply sulfur-based sprays (wettable sulfur 3g/L)
Spray neem oil as early preventive
Practice mixed cropping to reduce spread
prevention: Sow at recommended time (avoid late sowing)
Destroy volunteer and alternate host plants
Monitor regularly and spray at first sign of pustules

symptoms: Irregular light green and dark green mosaic pattern on leaves
Leaf curling, puckering, or distortion
Stunted plant growth
Mottled or deformed fruits with reduced quality
cause: Various viruses (Tobacco Mosaic Virus, Cucumber Mosaic Virus, etc.). Spread by aphids, whiteflies, contaminated tools, or seed. No cure once infected.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Control aphid/whitefly vectors with neem oil (5ml/L)
Use reflective mulch to repel vectors
Wash hands and tools with milk solution between plants
chemical_treatment: No direct chemical cure for the virus itself
prevention: Control insect vectors from seedling stage
Avoid tobacco use near susceptible crops (TMV)

symptoms: Galls (knots/swellings) on roots of varying sizes
Stunted growth and yellowing of plants
Wilting during mid-day despite adequate moisture
Poor root development and reduced yield
cause: Soil-borne nematode Meloidogyne incognita. Penetrates roots and induces gall formation. Favored by sandy, warm soils. Often complicated by secondary fungal infections.
organic_treatment: Apply neem cake @ 250kg/ha in soil before planting
Use Paecilomyces lilacinus @ 5kg/ha as biocontrol
Grow marigold (Tagetes) as trap crop or intercrop
Apply Trichoderma viride @ 5kg/ha in soil
prevention: Practice crop rotation with cereals, mustard, or marigold
Deep summer ploughing to expose nematodes to sun
Avoid continuous cultivation of susceptible crops

symptoms: Raised brown corky lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits
Lesions have water-soaked margin and yellow halo
Severely affected leaves drop prematurely
Fruits with canker spots have reduced market value
cause: Bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas citri. Spread by wind-driven rain, contaminated tools, and infected planting material. Enters through stomata and wounds.
organic_treatment: Prune and destroy infected branches (disinfect tools after each cut)
Spray Bordeaux mixture 1% as preventive
Apply copper-based organic sprays
Maintain tree vigor through balanced nutrition
prevention: Windbreaks around orchards to reduce wind-driven rain
Avoid working in orchards when foliage is wet
Disinfect pruning tools with bleach solution
Apply preventive copper sprays before monsoon

symptoms: Dark brown circular spots with concentric rings on leaves
Spots enlarge and coalesce causing premature defoliation
Dark streaks on stems and pods
Seeds become shriveled and discolored
cause: Fungal pathogen Alternaria brassicae. Seed-borne and survives on crop debris. Favored by cool (18-25°C), humid weather with intermittent rainfall.
organic_treatment: Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride @ 4g/kg
Spray neem oil (5ml/L) at early infection
Remove lower infected leaves
Apply bio-agents as foliar spray
prevention: Clean cultivation and removal of crop residues
Timely sowing to avoid peak infection period

symptoms: Reddening of internal cane tissue with white transverse patches
Withering and drying of third and fourth leaf from top
Discoloration at nodes visible when cane is split
Foul alcoholic smell from infected cane
cause: Fungal pathogen Colletotrichum falcatum. Enters through sett buds and grows internally. Favored by waterlogged conditions and warm (28-32°C) weather.
organic_treatment: Treat setts with Trichoderma viride @ 4g/kg before planting
Soak setts in Carbendazim 0.1% solution for 30 minutes
Remove and destroy infected clumps immediately
Practice field sanitation
prevention: Practice crop rotation with rice or legumes
Ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging
Remove ratoon crops from infected fields

symptoms: Small dark brown to black circular spots on leaves
Spots may have yellow halo
Heavy spotting causes premature defoliation
Early defoliation leads to immature pod development
cause: Fungal pathogens (late leaf spot: Cercosporidium personatum, early leaf spot: Cercospora arachidicola). Spread by wind and rain splash.
organic_treatment: Apply neem oil (5ml/L) at early stage
Spray Trichoderma viride @ 4g/L
Remove heavily infected leaves
Apply organic sulfur sprays

symptoms: Yellowing of older leaves starting from margin
Leaves droop and hang around pseudostem ('skirt' appearance)
Splitting of pseudostem base
Brown/reddish discoloration of vascular tissue in pseudostem cross-section
cause: Soil-borne fungus Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense. Persists in soil for decades. Spread through infected planting material, soil, and water.
organic_treatment: Remove and destroy entire infected plant including rhizome
Apply Trichoderma viride @ 50g/plant in soil
Drench surrounding area with Pseudomonas fluorescens
Apply neem cake @ 1kg/pit around plant base
chemical_treatment: Carbendazim 50% WP @ 2g/L as soil drench (limited effectiveness)
No effective chemical control — focus on prevention
prevention: Use resistant varieties (Grand Naine is moderately resistant)
Practice crop rotation for 3-5 years with paddy
Avoid waterlogging and ensure proper drainage
